info.name: Soil/Water Table
info.description: Abiotic reservoir of water and essential minerals including nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, and trace elements critical for primary productivity

info.name: Sun
info.description: Primary energy source providing photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) at approximately 1000 W/m² driving all ecosystem processes

info.name: Adjacent Ecosystems
info.description: Neighboring biological systems receiving organic material through migration corridors, seed dispersal, and nutrient transfer

info.name: Soil System
info.description: Edaphic substrate receiving and processing organic waste through decomposition into humus and available nutrients

info.name: Ecosystem
info.description: Complex adaptive biological system exhibiting emergent properties through trophic energy flows, nutrient cycling, and population dynamics across multiple temporal and spatial scales. Following Bertalanffy: 'The ecosystem maintains itself in a continuous inflow and outflow, building up and breaking down of components, never being in equilibrium but maintaining a steady state.' Mobus 7-tuple: (Structure=trophic levels, Function=energy/nutrient cycling, History=succession, Complexity=biodiversity interactions, Boundary=biogeographic limits, Environment=abiotic factors, Relations=predator-prey dynamics)

info.name: Ecosystem Boundaries
info.description: Biogeographic and climatic boundaries defining species distributions, limiting factors, and ecological niche parameters

info.name: Nutrient Uptake Network
info.description: Mycorrhizal associations, root systems, and membrane transport mechanisms facilitating resource acquisition

interfaces.protocol: 1. Soil minerals dissolved → 2. Root hairs absorb nutrients → 3. Xylem transport activated → 4. Cellular uptake completed → 5. Metabolic integration achieved

info.name: Photosynthetic Apparatus
info.description: Chloroplast-containing tissues, light-harvesting complexes, and carbon fixation machinery capturing solar radiation

interfaces.protocol: 1. Photons absorbed by chlorophyll → 2. Electron transport chain activated → 3. ATP and NADPH generated → 4. Carbon dioxide fixed → 5. Glucose synthesized

info.name: Biomass Export Channels
info.description: Migration pathways, seed dispersal vectors, and nutrient flow corridors connecting to adjacent ecosystems

interfaces.protocol: 1. Biomass production quantified → 2. Export vectors identified → 3. Transport mechanisms activated → 4. Adjacent system uptake → 5. Ecosystem connectivity maintained

info.name: Decomposer Interface
info.description: Saprotrophic organisms, detrital pathways, and mineralization processes returning nutrients to soil system

interfaces.protocol: 1. Dead organic matter detected → 2. Enzymatic breakdown initiated → 3. Nutrient mineralization performed → 4. Soil incorporation completed → 5. Nutrient availability restored

info.name: Decomposers
info.description: Saprotrophic bacteria, fungi, and detritivores performing essential mineralization functions through enzymatic breakdown of complex organic compounds into bioavailable nutrients

info.name: Microbial Membrane Systems
info.description: Cell walls, plasma membranes, and extracellular enzyme complexes enabling decomposition processes

info.name: Carnivores
info.description: Secondary and tertiary consumers including apex predators, mesopredators, and specialized hunters regulating herbivore populations through predation pressure and behavioral modification

info.name: Territorial Boundaries
info.description: Home ranges, hunting territories, and resource defense zones defining predator spatial ecology

info.name: Primary Producers
info.description: Autotrophic organisms including terrestrial plants, algae, and chemosynthetic bacteria converting inorganic carbon into organic compounds via photosynthesis and chemosynthesis

info.name: Photosynthetic Membranes
info.description: Chloroplast thylakoids, cell walls, and light-harvesting antenna complexes enabling energy capture and carbon fixation

info.name: Energy Production Interface
info.description: Photosystem complexes and carbon fixation pathways providing chemical energy to ecosystem

interfaces.protocol: 1. Light absorption optimized → 2. Electron transport activated → 3. ATP synthesis completed → 4. Carbon fixation performed → 5. Energy transfer initiated

info.name: Herbivores
info.description: Primary consumers including grazers, browsers, granivores, and filter feeders converting plant biomass into animal tissue through specialized digestive adaptations

info.name: Digestive System Architecture
info.description: Rumen, cecum, specialized gut microbiomes, and enzymatic pathways enabling plant material processing and nutrient extraction

info.name: Grazing Pressure Interface
info.description: Feeding behavior, plant selection, and population dynamics affecting primary producer communities

interfaces.protocol: 1. Plant material selected → 2. Mechanical breakdown initiated → 3. Microbial fermentation performed → 4. Nutrient absorption completed → 5. Energy transfer achieved

info.name: Food Web Controller
info.description: Cybernetic regulatory hub coordinating trophic cascades, energy allocation, and population dynamics through predator-prey interactions, competition, and mutualistic relationships

info.name: Trophic Interaction Network
info.description: Complex web of feeding relationships, competitive exclusion principles, and coevolutionary dynamics maintaining ecosystem stability

info.name: Predation Control Interface
info.description: Top-down regulatory mechanisms controlling herbivore populations through predation pressure

interfaces.protocol: 1. Prey density assessed → 2. Hunting efficiency optimized → 3. Population pressure applied → 4. Carrying capacity adjusted → 5. Trophic balance maintained

info.name: Decomposition Regulation Interface
info.description: Dead organic matter allocation and decomposer community management for optimal nutrient cycling

interfaces.protocol: 1. Detrital input quantified → 2. Decomposer capacity assessed → 3. Nutrient release timed → 4. Soil fertility optimized → 5. Cycling efficiency maximized

info.name: Herbivore Regulation Interface
info.description: Bottom-up and top-down controls managing primary consumer populations and grazing pressure

interfaces.protocol: 1. Grazing pressure monitored → 2. Plant biomass assessed → 3. Carrying capacity calculated → 4. Population controls activated → 5. Sustainable grazing maintained

info.name: Primary Production Interface
info.description: Energy flow coordination from autotrophic production to higher trophic levels

interfaces.protocol: 1. Primary productivity measured → 2. Energy allocation calculated → 3. Trophic transfer efficiency optimized → 4. Food web stability assessed → 5. Energy flow maintained

info.name: Water and Minerals
info.description: Essential water molecules and dissolved inorganic nutrients including nitrates, phosphates, sulfates, and micronutrients for biological processes

info.name: Solar Radiation
info.description: Photosynthetically active radiation (400-700nm wavelength) providing approximately 1000 W/m² energy flux driving primary production

info.name: Biomass
info.description: Total living organic matter including plant tissues, animal biomass, and microbial communities produced through photosynthetic carbon fixation

info.name: Dead Organic Matter
info.description: Deceased organisms, leaf litter, fecal matter, and organic detritus entering decomposition pathways for nutrient mineralization

info.name: Energy Availability
info.description: Net primary productivity and gross primary productivity signals indicating photosynthetic capacity and energy availability for higher trophic levels

info.name: Resource Processing Rate
info.description: Herbivore grazing efficiency, plant matter conversion rates, and population density metrics indicating ecosystem carrying capacity

info.name: Predation Pressure
info.description: Carnivore hunting success, prey selection patterns, and population control mechanisms regulating herbivore communities

info.name: Decomposition Targets
info.description: Dead organic matter allocation, decomposition rates, and nutrient mineralization schedules optimizing soil fertility and nutrient cycling
